channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Emergency Workers Rushed to Scene of Russian Missile Attack. Then Another Missile Came.
item.description: Seven people, including a rescuer, were killed and dozens more were injured in the successive missile strikes on a small city in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of a Russian strike in Pokrovsk, Ukraine, on Tuesday morning.

item.title: Turbulent Waters: How the Black Sea Became a Hot Spot in the War
item.description: The Black Sea, a largely overlooked part of the war in Ukraine, is suddenly a cauldron of military and geopolitical tensions. The region is deeply important to both Moscow, Ukraine and the West.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Russian marines during Navy Day celebrations in Russia’s Black Sea port of Novorossiysk last month. The Black Sea is suddenly a cauldron of military and geopolitical tensions.

item.title: UAE, a US Ally, Looks to China and Russia for Deeper Ties
item.description: The United Arab Emirates, which has translated its wealth into outsize global influence, is diverging from U.S. foreign policy — particularly when it comes to isolating Russia and limiting ties with China.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Andrea DiCenzo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The marina district in Dubai. The Emirates has thrived on an influx of Russian money, oil and gold, fueling a feeding frenzy in real estate.

item.title: Ireland Says Goodbye to Sinéad O’Connor at Funeral Procession
item.description: In the coastal town of Bray, south of Dublin, the site of Ms. O’Connor’s last Irish home, mourners gathered to pay their respects to the singer.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:description: A hearse carrying the coffin of Sinead O’Connor passed outside her former home in Bray, Ireland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Hopes for Dialogue Dim in Niger as Junta Clings to Power
item.description: One of Niger’s coup leaders rejected a U.S. diplomat’s request to release the country’s democratically elected president and bring back constitutional order.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Members of a military council that staged a coup in Niger attending a rally at a stadium in the capital, Niamey, on Sunday.

item.title: Weather Punishes Europe, With Portugal Wildfires and Slovenia Floods
item.description: The extreme weather across the continent this summer has destroyed huge amounts of land, forced many to evacuate, and in some cases caused deaths.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Dropping water over a fire in Apesia, southern Cyprus, on Monday.

item.title: Swiss Museum Cashier Pockets Over $1 Million in Yearslong Scam
item.description: A ticket seller at an art museum in Switzerland spent more than a decade skimming cash.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Tickets at the Beyeler Foundation, one of Switzerland’s most visited museums, cost nearly $29 for a regular adult.

item.title: The Taliban Won but These Afghans Fought On
item.description: But the Afghan resistance movement is no match for the Taliban’s military might.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim

item.title: Video Shows China Blasting Water Cannon at Philippines Coast Guard Boat
item.description: The clash, in which a Chinese ship blocked 2 Philippine vessels, is the latest in a hotly contested region of the South China Sea.
item.media:credit: Philippine Coast Guard, via Associated Press

item.title: Xi Remade China’s Military. Now a Purge Threatens its Image.
item.description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, set out to clean up the military a decade ago. But now his crown jewel, the missile force, is under a shadow.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, has taken pride in turning the 98 million-strong Communist Party and the Chinese military into unquestioning enforcers of his rule.

item.title: Ukraine’s Marines Urge Patience With Counterattack Against Russia
item.description: Journalists from The Times spent two weeks with troops from brigades trained and supplied by NATO to get their take on how, and where, the counteroffensive is going.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sánchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops near the southern front line.

item.title: South Korean Cities Play Matchmaker to Singles Wanting to Mingle
item.description: Singles are signing up in droves for city-hosted blind-dating events, but some point to their inability to address real issues with family planning.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon

item.title: UK Moves First Group of Migrants to Barge
item.description: A small group of migrants was transferred to the Bibby Stockholm, a divisive symbol of the Conservative government’s immigration stance.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The Bibby Stockholm, foreground, a barge that can accommodate 500 people, was moored in Portland, southwest England, on Monday.

item.title: Gaza Protests Struggle to Gain Traction as Police Crack Down
item.description: Demonstrators’ efforts to rally against Hamas, including at protests on Monday, have been foiled by a heavy security presence.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:description: A Palestinian girl in the Gaza Strip tries to stay cool during a heat wave last week when power outages compounded frustrations with Hamas.

item.title: TSMC Will Build a Semiconductor Plant in Germany
item.description: TSMC, the world’s largest maker of semiconductors, said it would invest $3.8 billion in a joint project with three German industrial firms.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and John Liu
item.media:description: TSMC announced a joint project to build a production facility for microchips in eastern Germany; the plant would be its first in Europe.

item.title: UK Expands Sanctions List to Target Russia’s Weapons Suppliers
item.description: New measures announced Tuesday will affect businesses in Turkey, Dubai and Iran, as well as individuals that Britain says have supplied weaponry or components needed to sustain Russia’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle

item.title: British Museum Stabbing: Man Wounded
item.description: The stabbing outside the popular tourist attraction was not related to terrorism, the police said. A suspect has been arrested.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Jordan Pettitt/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A crowd gathers at the entrance to the British Museum on Tuesday after a man was stabbed outside the building.

item.title: Typhoon Khanun Threatens Japan Again, With South Korea Next
item.description: The storm, which battered Okinawa last week, made an unusual zigzag move and now threatens the Japanese island of Kyushu.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A tree in Naha, Japan, last week, uprooted by Typhoon Khanun’s high winds.

item.title: As Weather Threats Loom, Even Chimps Learn to Shelter in Place
item.description: How do you teach 300 chimpanzees to seek safety in a storm? With cowbells, sound machines and a bright orange Frisbee.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Emil T. Lippe
item.media:credit: Emil T. Lippe for The New York Times

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Upheaval in the Chinese military.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader.

item.title: Ukraine Says Russian Missiles Struck Town of Pokrovsk, Killing 5
item.description: The strikes hit the center of the small city in eastern Ukraine twice within 40 minutes, officials said. At least 31 people were injured.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Rescue workers at a residential building destroyed by a Russian missile strike in Pokrovsk, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Elite Chinese Generals Ousted
item.description: Also, South Korea relocates an international scout convention as a typhoon looms.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, has taken pride in turning the 98 million-strong Communist Party and the Chinese military into unquestioning enforcers of his rule.

item.title: Foreign Ministers of China and Russia Confer Phone After Jeddah Talks
item.description: China underscored its desire to “actively promote” efforts to end the war in Ukraine “on any multilateral occasion.”
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia with China’s top diplomat, Wang Yi, last month on the sidelines of Southeast Asian talks in Jakarta, Indonesia, in a photo released by the Russian Foreign Ministry.

item.title: Ukraine Replaces the Soviet Symbol on the Motherland Monument
item.description: The Motherland Monument — a 335-foot-tall stainless steel behemoth towering over Ukraine’s capital — was unveiled in 1981 and designed to assert Soviet invincibility.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Sarah Eckinger

item.title: South Korea Tells Scouts to Quit World Jamboree Site as Typhoon Nears
item.description: The main campsite for the troubled gathering will be packed up and thousands of scouts will disperse across the country until the event ends on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: U.S. scouts preparing to leave the World Scout Jamboree campsite in Buan, South Korea, on Sunday.

item.title: Israeli Missile Strike Kills 4 Near Damascus, Syria Says
item.description: A report in Syrian state media said the attack had come from the Golan Heights. The four killed were soldiers, it said.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Monday Briefing: Khan Arrested in Pakistan
item.description: Also, diverted floodwaters provoke anger in China.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Imran Khan, center, at an office of Lahore High Court in Lahore, Pakistan, last month.

item.title: At Least 24 Killed in Minibus Crash in Morocco
item.description: The vehicle overturned at a curve on its way to a weekly town market southeast of Marrakesh, officials said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Families and security officials outside a morgue in Demnate, Morocco, on Sunday, after a deadly traffic accident that morning.

item.title: Deadline to Junta in Niger From ECOWAS Leaders Runs Out
item.description: A deadline given by a bloc of other West African nations to the Nigerien military junta to reinstate the ousted president ran out with no sign of a military intervention by neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Omar Hama Saley
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: Protesters on Thursday outside the National Assembly in Niamey, Niger’s capital.

item.title: Pakistan Train Derails, Killing at Least 30
item.description: An express train carrying at least 950 passengers was traveling from Karachi to Havelian when 10 carriages fell off the tracks, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Rescue crews worked at the site of a train derailment on Sunday near Nawabshah, in southern Pakistan.

item.title: In Egypt, Public Classrooms Are Empty as Private Tutors Get Rich
item.description: In a country hobbled by economic crisis, families often turn to private education centers instead of schools to seek better futures for their children, sometimes even sacrificing food to pay for lessons.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Nariman El-Mofty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Egyptian students crammed into the Excellent-Oxford Tutoring Center in a suburb of Cairo for a five-hour private math lesson.

item.title: Putin’s Forever War
item.description: Vladimir Putin wants to lead Russians into a civilizational conflict with the West far larger than Ukraine. Will they follow him?
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Putin’s Forever War

item.title: ‘Barbie’ Is a Sleeper Hit in China
item.description: The movie has exceeded box office expectations, as China’s female moviegoers celebrate a film that addresses women’s rights head-on.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Siyi Zhao
item.media:description: Despite its limited availability in China, the movie “Barbie” has quickly become widely discussed on Chinese social media, setting off its own mini-mania in some circles.

item.title: Ukraine War Expands Beyond Established Battlefields
item.description: Ukraine has grown bolder, firing drones at Moscow, while Russian forces have turned to regular attacks on the Black Sea, a crucial economic lifeline.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Vivek Shankar and Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damaged buildings in Kharkiv, a city in eastern Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Swiss Women Sue Government Over Climate Change Protections
item.description: A group of Swiss women over 64 has filed a lawsuit against Switzerland with Europe’s top human rights court, saying the country has violated their rights by failing to curb emissions.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Members of KlimaSeniorinnen, or Senior Women for Climate Protection, in 2020 with Marie Toussaint, third from right, a French environmental activist and member of the European Parliament, in Strasbourg, France.

item.title: Victim of Mass Attack in South Korea Dies
item.description: The victim was one of 14 people hurt in a car-and-stabbing rampage on Thursday in a city near Seoul. She had been hit by the car.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A police officer cordoning off the scene of the attack in Seongnam, South Korea, on Thursday.

item.title: Henri Konan Bédié, Ivory Coast President Deposed in a Coup, Dies at 89
item.description: As a longtime power broker he helped make his West African country an economic dynamo, but in office he fomented ethnic divisions and cracked down on dissent.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Henri Konan Bédié in 2020. He played a dominant role in Ivorian politics over six decades. His quiet confidence and back-room influence earned him the nickname “the Sphinx of Daoukro,” after his hometown.

item.title: Palestinian Kills Israeli in Tel Aviv, a Day After West Bank Violence
item.description: A gunman from Jenin, West Bank, shot and killed an Israeli security guard on Saturday. It came the evening after a Palestinian was killed in a fight with Israeli settlers.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A street in Tel Aviv where an Israeli security guard was shot on Saturday by a Palestinian gunman. The victim was pronounced dead at a nearby hospital.

item.title: Pope Francis Declines to Condemn Russia at Fatima Shrine in Portugal
item.description: “It’s not enough just to listen — he has to do something,” said Dmytro Bohak, one of about 500 young Ukrainian pilgrims who attended the event and staged a demonstration.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Patricia De Melo Moreira/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pope Francis waving to pilgrims in Fátima, Portugal, on Saturday.

item.title: ‘Rooftopping’ Is Popular on Instagram, but the Risks Are High
item.description: “Rooftoppers” get a thrill from taking photos atop skyscrapers and sharing them on social media. Detractors call them reckless.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle and Tiffany May

item.title: Canada Moves Forward With New Tech Tax
item.description: An international overhaul to tax tech companies is at a standstill, so Canada is forging ahead with another plan.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: A Meta sign outside of the company’s headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif., in March.

item.title: Imran Khan Sentenced to Prison in Pakistan
item.description: The former prime minister of Pakistan was taken into custody, sentenced to three years after a court found him guilty of illegally selling state gifts and concealing the assets.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan signing bond documents at an office of the high court last month in Lahore.

item.title: Arrests for Online Threats of Copycat Attacks in South Korea
item.description: Posts online in the wake of recent stabbing assaults specified sites for copycat attacks. They prompted swift police action in a nation rattled by the random violence.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Police officers at the scene of a stabbing in Seoul on July 21 that left one person dead and three others injured. There was a second stabbing attack near the city this month.

item.title: Niger is Latest African Country Where France’s Fortunes are Fading
item.description: A recent military takeover in Niger has thrown into uncertainty the future of France’s presence in West and Central Africa, raising doubts about the future of U.S. military involvement there, too.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Protesters holding the flag of Niger on Thursday, the nation’s independence day, in the capital, Niamey.

item.title: Jolted by a Mutiny, Putin Works the Crowds
item.description: His contained interactions with crowds this summer are a noticeable change for the Russian leader, who disdains retail politics and operated in extreme seclusion during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: A photograph provided by the Russian state news media showed President Vladimir V. Putin holding a child in Kronstadt, near St. Petersburg, last month.

item.title: An Israeli City Where Compromise and Division Swim Side by Side
item.description: At a time when Israeli Jews can seem irreconcilably divided, an unusual swimming center in the city of Rehovot illustrates the compromises that many Israelis make daily.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Gabby Sobelman
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children playing in the religious pool during its males-only hours in Rehovot, Israel, last month.

item.title: Thousands of Scouts Leaving South Korea Jamboree Early
item.description: The British, Singaporean and U.S. scouting organizations cited health concerns for their departure from a much-anticipated youth event in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Scouts resting in the shade at the World Scout Jamboree in Buan, South Korea, on Friday.

item.title: Battle at Sea Intensifies as Ukraine Drone Hits 2nd Russian Ship in 2 Days
item.description: In addition to the strike on an oil tanker, Ukraine issued a warning that commercial ships using any of six Russian Black Sea ports would be considered military targets.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Christiaan Triebert
item.media:credit: Planet Labs PBC, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A satellite image released by Planet Labs showed a damaged Russian warship near the port of Novorossiysk, Russia, on Friday.

item.title: How a U.S. Tech Mogul Used Nonprofits to Sow Chinese Propaganda
item.description: The Times unraveled a financial network that stretches from Chicago to Shanghai and uses American nonprofits to push Chinese talking points worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl, David A. Fahrenthold, Lynsey Chutel and Ishaan Jhaveri
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Neville Roy Singham, right, in 2016 with the activist Jodie Evans. In 2017, they married and he sold his tech firm.

item.title: Ukraine Invites Talks in Saudi Arabia as an Effort to Weaken Russia
item.description: Some 40 countries that have largely remained on the sidelines of the war were invited to talks on Saturday in Saudi Arabia, as Ukraine redoubles international efforts to isolate Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Vivian Nereim and David Pierson
item.media:credit: Saudi Press Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Saudi state media showed President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in May in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Ukraine Hits a Distant Russian Ship, Showing Reach of Naval Drones
item.description: The attack damaged the warship hundreds of miles from Ukrainian-held territory, as Kyiv increasingly tries to bring the war home to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Christiaan Triebert

item.title: Greece Will Limit Acropolis Visits as Europe Fights Tourist Crush
item.description: Greece is trying to curb overcrowding and prevent damage at its most popular archaeological site. Other European destinations are also cracking down.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Home to the Parthenon, the Acropolis has attracted up to 23,000 visitors each day. The new limits will cap visitors at 20,000 a day.

item.title: ‘Too Patriarchal’ Father in India Now Champions Women’s Rights
item.description: A delivery room epiphany transformed a village headman into an unlikely and highly successful campaigner against prenatal sex testing, which often led to aborting female fetuses.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunil Jaglan, center, discussing health issues with women in a farming village in Haryana State in India, where he has led a campaign against prenatal sex testing.

item.title: Young Catholics Come Together, if Not Their Views
item.description: As young Catholics gathered from around the world in Portugal, their desires for the future of the church were as varied as the countries they came from.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jose Sena Goulao
item.media:description: Crowds greeting Pope Francis in Lisbon on Wednesday.

item.title: Supreme Court in India Gives Rahul Gandhi a Path Back to Parliament
item.description: India’s main opposition leader was kicked out of the legislature after a defamation case that his allies called politically motivated. He can also now run in next year’s elections.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli
item.media:description: Rahul Gandhi, center, was barred from Parliament after a lower court in the prime minister’s home state gave him a two-year prison sentence.

item.title: What to Know About Novorossiysk, the Russian Port Attacked by Ukraine
item.description: The seaport is one of Russia’s largest by volume and among the biggest in Europe, crucial to the export of Russian grain, oil, and other products to countries around the world.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: Oil tankers moored in Novorossiysk, Russia, last October.

item.title: Anger in China Over Flooding of Towns, in Part, to Save Beijing
item.description: A provincial leader set off an outcry by urging cities to serve as a “moat” for the capital, as diverted floodwaters sent scores of residents fleeing.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: A rescue worker pulling a boat carrying residents in a flooded area near Zhuozhou, China, on Thursday.

item.title: Andrew Tate Is Released From House Arrest in Romania
item.description: The online influencer and his brother, Tristan Tate, must remain in the country while they await trial on charges of human trafficking, a court in Bucharest ruled.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Matei Barbulescu
item.media:description: Andrew Tate, center, and his brother Tristan, right, inside the Bucharest Court of Appeals building this week.
